prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure this out. The user is asking if the person who wrote the scenario is in the wrong. The situation is about splitting bills in a relationship.

First, the guy and his girlfriend live together. He pays all the bills and rent because she only works part-time. Then there's an incident where he forgets his wallet, and she gets upset about paying for takeout under $40. He's now considering making her contribute more, even though he admits she can't pay a lot. 

Hmm. So the question is whether he's in the wrong. Let me break it down. 

He's been paying everything until now, maybe expecting her to pitch in a little. But he's using a small incident as a catalyst. Is it fair to make her pay some bills because of one time she got upset? On the other hand, maybe he's right that she should start contributing if she can, even a little. 

But wait, she works part-time. If her income is low, maybe her ability to contribute is limited. He mentions that her little income might not cover expenses, but he's making her start paying some bills. Is that fair? Also, the way he's framing it seems a bit harsh. The takeout was only $40, and he's making a big deal about her attitude. 

He's acting like the issue is about splitting costs, but maybe it's more about the resentment building up. He might be using that incident as an excuse to change the financial arrangement. But is it right to hold one incident against her? Also, maybe he should have communicated earlier about wanting to share expenses instead of waiting until this happened. 

On the other hand, if he's always paid everything, maybe she didn't realize he expected her to help. But if he's now using this as a reason to make her pay some bills, is that fair? Especially if she can't pay a lot? Maybe he's overreacting because he's hurt or feels unappreciated. 

The problem is whether he's in the wrong. If he's making her pay because of his frustration over one incident, that could be unfair. But if he's trying to establish a more balanced financial arrangement because she's able to contribute a bit, then maybe it's reasonable. 

But since he's using a single incident as the reason and seems to be more upset about her reaction than the actual cost, it might be that he's overreacting. Also, he's the one in the question, so if he's making her pay some bills over this, maybe he's the one being unreasonable. 

So, considering all factors, the answer might be A (he's in the wrong) because he's overreacting to a small incident and using it as a justification to change the financial arrangement without considering her limitations or communicating properly. Alternatively, maybe B if he's just setting a new expectation. But the way he's handling it seems harsh.
